Mission UAVs e xperienced signal interference, assessed as caused by probable jamming on 147 occasions, including 25 instances experienced by long -range UAVs, while flying on both sides of the contact line.

The Mission continued to m onitor the disengagement areas near Stanytsia Luhanska, Zolote and Petrivske. It again recorded ceasefire violations and spotted people ins ide the disengagement areas near Zolote and Petrivske.

The SMM also continued to observe weapons in areas from which they should have been withdrawn in accordance with the Minsk agreements.

The SMM corroborated reports of one civilian casualty in Donetsk Region, an 82 -year-old man who sus- tained fatal injuries in government-controlled Pavlopil. This brings the total number of confirmed civilian casualties since the beginning of 2021 to 85 (16 fatalities and 69 injured).

The Mission followe d up on reports of damage to 29 civilian properties on both sides of the contact line in Done tsk and Luhansk regions. Overall since the beginning of 2021, the SMM has confirmed damage to 197 civilian objects and infrastructure sites.

The Mission continued to m onitor the s ituation of civilians, including at five entry -exit che ckpoints and the corresponding checkpoints of the armed formations, of which two were open (one daily and the other only two days a week).

The Mission also published a thematic report on restrictions to civilian freedom of movement at crossing points along the contact line and the impact of these restrictions.

The SMM continued to facilitate the operation of the Donetsk Filtration Station and the pumping s tation near Vasylivka, providing water to 380,000 and 1.2 million civilians respectively, on both sides of the contact line.

Since the beginning of the year, the Mission has facilitated and monitored windows of silence to enable repairs and mainte nance of 94 public infrastructure sites on both sides of the contact line (59 in Donetsk region and 35 in Luhansk region), providing water, electricity, gas and communication services to over five million civilians.
